title: ASX bolsters its ability to clamp down on rule breakers
text:
The ASX's biggest rule changes have been reserved for those stocks and listed investment companies which violate the bourse's listing rules.

The exchange has tightened its long-term suspension rule, allowing it to delist companies which fail to lodge documents with the ASX for a continuous period of one year after the relevant deadline.

Previously, companies were only able to be suspended after not lodging documents for three years.

"This issue generated the largest number of submissions in the consultation," the ASX said in its response to submissions.

"The changes were supported by five respondents but, unsurprisingly, the specific changes to ASX’s long-term suspended entity policy were opposed by some listed entities which were vulnerable to removal under the revised policy and their advisers."

The changes were to have been put into effect from July 2019, but the ASX has revised that to February 2020, allowing companies another seven months to comply with the new standard.

The new rules also allow the bourse to automatically suspend listed investment companies and listed investment trusts for failing to disclose their monthly net tangible asset value on time.

Advertisement

While some respondents to the consultations argued the punishment was too harsh for what could be an an administrative lapse or a technical problem, the ASX disagreed.

"ASX notes that investment entities have up to 14 days after month end

to lodge their monthly NTA announcement," it said. "ASX generally contacts entities ahead of the deadline for automatic removal under [listing rule] 17.5, so they have advance warning of their potential suspension. A period of 14 days should be more than ample time to address an administrative slip or technical problem."

The ASX had also proposed mandatory reporting of LIC portfolios, however that has been sidelined for the time being to allow for more consultation.

The exchange will introduce a censure power, targeting individual rule breakers, which it believes will be a more effective deterrent than a fine.

The bourse did note it would “only exercise its power of censure against an entity where it considers the entity’s breach of the listing rules to be egregious and after first providing the entity with an opportunity to comment on the proposed terms of the censure”.

“It’s important that ASX keeps evolving the listing rules so they remain contemporary, address emerging compliance issues, and continue to serve the interests of issuers, investors, and the Australian economy," Mr Lewis said.
description: The Australian Securities Exchange has toughened its listing rules in a bid to improve the integrity of the market.
